company.name: OpenX Technologies, Inc.
company.business_description: OpenX operates a programmatic advertising exchange that helps publishers of Web sites and mobile applications monetize their properties through advertising. The company provides a real-time bidding platform for conducting auctions for ad space and contracts with publishers and advertising technology companies to aggregate and sell advertising inventory.

commissioners: Kristin Cohen, Acting Associate Director, Division of Privacy & Identity Protection
Mark Eichorn, Assistant Director, Division of Privacy and Identity Protection
Sarah Choi, Attorney, Division of Privacy & Identity Protection
Kevin Moriarty, Attorney, Division of Privacy & Identity Protection
case_info.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

complaint.factual_background: OpenX Technologies, Inc. operated a programmatic advertising exchange that collected precise location data (BSSIDs) from consumers who had denied or not granted location permissions, using a backdoor method to access this data from the ARP cache instead of the sanctioned location API. Additionally, OpenX collected personal information including location data and persistent identifiers from hundreds of child-directed mobile apps without obtaining parental consent or providing required COPPA notices, despite having actual knowledge through its human review process that these apps were directed to children under 13.

representations_made.description: Consumers can opt out of OpenX's collection, use, and transfer of precise location data by using location services controls in mobile device settings
representations_made.quoted_text: Opting Out for Location Data: You may opt out of our collection, use, and transfer of precise location data by using the location services controls in your mobile device's settings.

representations_made.description: OpenX does not engage in activities that require parental notice or consent under COPPA
representations_made.quoted_text: Children's Online Privacy Protection Act Notice. OpenX does not engage in activities that require parental notice or consent under the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA). If you believe that OpenX has inadvertently collected information from a child under 13 that is subject to parental notice and consent under COPPA, please contact OpenX using the contact information below to request deletion of the information.

representations_made.description: OpenX has an internal COPPA policy that identifies child-directed properties and places a COPPA flag for inventory from those properties
representations_made.quoted_text: In its Data Privacy and Information Security Frequently Asked Questions, OpenX also stated that it has an internal COPPA policy that identifies child-directed properties and places a COPPA flag for inventory from those properties.

counts.title: Deception – Location Data Collection Misrepresentation
counts.representation: OpenX represented that consumers can opt out of OpenX's collection, use, and transfer of precise location data by using the location services controls in their mobile device settings or by denying consent when prompted by a permission dialog box
counts.fact: Consumers could not opt out of OpenX's collection, use, and transfer of precise location data by using the location services controls in their mobile device settings or by using the permission dialog box within the App. OpenX collected and transferred the BSSID even if the consumer had not provided consent or had expressly denied permission to collect location data
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representations referred to in Paragraph 57 were false or misleading, and constitute a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Deception – COPPA Activities and Practices Misrepresentation
counts.representation: OpenX represented that it does not engage in activities that require parental notice or consent under COPPA, and that it identifies all child-directed properties and includes a COPPA flag to identify inventory from those properties
counts.fact: OpenX does engage in activities that require parental notice and consent under COPPA. Moreover, OpenX does not identify all child-directed properties, nor does it include a COPPA flag in bid requests to identify all child-directed inventory
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representations referred to in Paragraph 60 were false or misleading, and constitute a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: COPPA – Collection of Personal Information from Child-Directed Properties Without Consent and Proper Notice
counts.representation: OpenX is an operator of an online service with actual knowledge that it is collecting personal information directly from users of Web sites or online services directed to children. OpenX collected, used, and disclosed personal information including location information and persistent identifiers from users of child-directed Web sites and Apps
counts.fact: OpenX failed to: (a) provide sufficient notice on its Web site or online service of the information it collects from children, how it uses such information, its disclosure practices, and all other required content, in violation of Section 312.4(d) of the Rule; (b) provide direct notice to parents of the information it collects from children, how it uses such information, its disclosure practices, and all other required content, in violation of Sections 312.4(b) and (c) of the Rule; and (c) obtain verifiable parental consent before any collection or use of personal information from children, in violation of Section 312.5 of the Rule
counts.conclusion: Pursuant to Section 1303(c) of COPPA, 15 U.S.C. § 6502(c), and Section 18(d)(3) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 57(a)(d)(3), a violation of the Rule constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice in or affecting commerce, in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

definitions.Rule: the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312, or as the Rule may hereafter be amended.
definitions.child: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.collects: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.collection: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.Commission: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.delete: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.disclosure: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.Internet: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.online contact information: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.operator: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.parent: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.person: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.personal information: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.third party: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.verifiable consent: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.website or online service directed to ch: as defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.defendants: Bigmailbox.com, Inc. and its officers; Nolan Quan, individually and as an officer of the corporation; and each of the above's successors and assigns, agents, representatives, and employees.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against COPPA Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule as promulgated or as it may be modified in the future.

requirements.description: Must not violate any provision of the COPPA Rule
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, their successors and assigns, and their officers, agents, servants, employees and attorneys, and all persons in active concert or participation with any one or more of them who receive actual notice of this Consent Decree by personal service or otherwise, are hereby enjoined from violating, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, website, or other device, any provision of the Rule as promulgated and as it may be modified in the future.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy Practices
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any misrepresentation about the website's collection, use, or disclosure of children's personal information or security procedures.

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent privacy practices concerning children's information
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, their successors and assigns, and their officers, agents, servants, employees and attorneys, and all persons in active concert or participation with any one or more of them who receive actual notice of this Consent Decree by personal service or otherwise, are hereby enjoined, in connection with the operation of any website or other online service, from making any misrepresentation in the website's privacy policy or elsewhere about the website's collection, use or disclosure of children's personal information, or about the website's procedures to maintain the confidentiality, security, or integrity of children's personal information.

provisions.title: Consumer Education Notice Requirement
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must place a clear notice linking to the FTC's children's privacy resources in privacy policies, parent notices, and at information collection points.

requirements.description: Place FTC notice in privacy policy, parent notices, and at collection points
requirements.quoted_text: For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendants, and their successors and assigns, in connection with the operation of any website or online service directed in whole or in part to children, shall place a clear and conspicuous notice (1) within the privacy policy required to be posted on their website(s) by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b); (2) within the direct notice required to be sent to parents by Section 312.4(c) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c); and (3) at each location on their website(s) where personal information is collected, which states as follows in bold typeface: NOTICE: Visit www.ftc.gov/kidzprivacy for information from the Federal Trade Commission about protecting children's privacy online.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay a civil penalty of $35,000 to the United States.

requirements.quoted_text: Defendants Bigmailbox.com, Inc. and Nolan Quan, and their successors and assigns, shall pay to plaintiff a civil penalty, pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A), in the amount of thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000). Defendants are jointly and severally responsible for paying the penalty.

provisions.title: Payment Timing and Method
provisions.summary: Defendants must make payment on the date of entry of the Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check.

requirements.description: Submit payment on date of entry by certified or cashier's check
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants shall make the payment required by Paragraph 9 on the date of entry of this Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check made payable to the Treasurer of the United States and delivered to: the Office of Consumer Litigation, Civil Division, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, D.C. 20530, for appropriate disposition.

provisions.title: Default Payment Penalty
provisions.summary: If payment defaults for more than 10 days, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due.

requirements.description: Pay unpaid penalty with interest if default continues beyond 10 days
requirements.quoted_text: In the event of any default in payment, which default continues for ten (10) days beyond the due date of payment, the entire unpaid penalty, together with interest, as computed pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1961, from the date of default to the date of payment, shall immediately become due and payable.

provisions.title: Data Deletion Requirement
provisions.summary: Defendants must delete all personal information collected from children through their website prior to entry of the decree.

requirements.description: Delete all personal information collected from children
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall delete all personal information collected from children through www.bigmailbox.com prior to the date of entry of this Consent Decree.

provisions.title: Order Distribution to Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide the Consent Decree and compliance guide to current personnel with relevant responsibilities and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days.

requirements.description: Distribute decree and compliance guide to current personnel and obtain acknowledgments
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, within thirty days from the date of entry of this Consent decree, shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the Federal Trade Commission compliance guide entitled How to Comply with the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (Nov. 1999) ("compliance guide") (attached hereto as "Appendix B") to each of their current principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the operation of any website or online service subject to the Rule, and secure from each such person a signed statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide

requirements.description: Submit signed statement to Commission confirming compliance
requirements.quoted_text: and shall, within ten (10) days of complying with this paragraph, submit to the Commission a signed statement setting forth the fact and manner of defendants' compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide has been provided.

provisions.title: Order Distribution to Future Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide the Consent Decree and compliance guide to future personnel with relevant responsibilities and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days of hire.

requirements.description: Distribute decree and compliance guide to future personnel and obtain acknowledgments
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide to each of their future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all future employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the operation of any website or online service subject to the Rule, and secure from each such person a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide, within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities.

provisions.title: Initial Compliance Report
provisions.summary: Defendants must file a detailed written compliance report with the Commission within 60 days covering registration processes, privacy notices, parental consent methods, and security procedures.

requirements.description: File detailed compliance report with the Commission
requirements.quoted_text: Within sixty (60) days after entry of this Consent Decree, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall file with the Commission a written report setting forth in detail the manner and form in which they have complied and are complying with this Consent Decree.

provisions.title: Document Retention and Production
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must maintain compliance documents and make them available to the FTC within 7 days of request.

requirements.description: Maintain and produce compliance documents upon FTC request
requirements.quoted_text: For a period of five years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall maintain and make available to the Federal Trade Commission for inspection and copying within seven (7) days of the date of receipt of a written request, a print or electronic copy in HTML format of all documents demonstrating compliance with the terms and provisions of this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, a sample copy of every different information collection form, web page, or screen, and a sample copy of each different document containing any representation regarding defendants' collection, use, and disclosure practices pertaining to personal information.

provisions.title: Business Change Notification (Corporate)
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any business changes that may affect compliance obligations.

requirements.description: Notify Commission of business changes affecting compliance
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the business of defendant Bigmailbox.com, Inc. that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, any merger, incorporation, dissolution, assignment, sale, or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address.

provisions.title: Employment Change Notification (Individual)
provisions.summary: For three years, individual defendant Nolan Quan must notify the Commission of employment changes involving Internet-related businesses collecting personal information.

requirements.description: Notify Commission of employment or business changes
requirements.quoted_text: For a period of three (3) years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendant Nolan Quan shall notify the Commission of the discontinuance of his current business or employment, or of his employment with, direction or control of, or ownership interest of at least 5% in, any Internet-related business or service involving the collection of personal information online. The notice shall include defendant's new business address and telephone number, and a description of the nature of the business or employment and his duties and responsibilities.

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identification Number Provision
provisions.summary: Defendants must furnish their taxpayer identifying numbers to the FTC for debt collection purposes.

requirements.description: Provide taxpayer identifying numbers to the FTC
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants are hereby required, in accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701, to furnish to the Federal Trade Commission each of their taxpayer identifying numbers (social security number or employer identification number), which shall be used for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amount arising out of their relationship with the government.

provisions.title: Report Submission Instructions
provisions.summary: All reports, submissions, and notices must be sent by certified mail to the specified FTC address.

requirements.description: Submit all reports and notices by certified mail to designated FTC address
requirements.quoted_text: All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 12 - 19 of this Consent Decree shall be sent by certified mail to: Associate Director, Division of Advertising Practices, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20580, Attention: United States v. Bigmailbox, Inc., et al.

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction for interpretation, modification, enforcement, and punishment of violations of the Consent Decree.

requirements.description: Court retains jurisdiction for enforcement and modification
requirements.quoted_text: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to this Consent Decree to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.

duration.termination_text: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to this Consent Decree to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.
